question: Question_05_(b)
statement:
Let

\[\displaystyle
f(x) = \frac{2x^2}{x^2-1}\]

\textbf{(b)} Find all the \emph{x}- and \emph{y}-intercepts of $f$.
sols:
\textbf{x-intercept}\[f(x)\] has an x-intercept when $f(x) = 0$. So

\[0 = \frac{2x^2}{x^2-1}\]

Cross multiplying gives $2x^2 = 0$, which simplifies to $x = 0$. So the
x-intercept is $(0,0)$

\textbf{y-intercept}\[f(x)\] has an y-intercept when $x = 0$. Plugging
in \emph{x = 0} gives $f(0) = 0$.

So the y-intercept is the same as the x-intercept, $(0,0)$
hints:
Recall that $f(x)$ has a y-intercept when \emph{x = 0} and an
x-intercept when the function is zero.
